entry.title: Get bored with me: The BearBored Challenge
entry.summary: This post was inspired by Sit. What is this? I am bored. I want to get bored a bit more. Get bored with me. Come join. The goal? The goal of the challenge is to waste time. To be as unproductive. To "bear the boredness". (I swear I could think of a better name) You will need... A timer (I use the iPhone built-in Clock app. Feel free to choose your own.) A notebook / sheets of paper A pen How to get started: Step 1: Decide on how long you want to get bored. 15-60 minutes. 5-12 sessions with each session 3-5 minutes long. Step 2: Write down on your notebook a list of numbers from 1 to X. (X = the number of sessions you chose). 1.54:59 Step 3: Start the timer, do nothing and get bored. Step 4: When each session ends, think of one word that captures the theme of that session. It can be a noun, a verb, an adjective; an emotion, an action, some random vocabulary. Your choice! Write that word down next to the numbered list. 1.54:59 Distraction That is all! Note: These are rules I follow when I am doing the challenge. Feel free not to. No usage of pen and paper besides writing down the keyword. By all means think but let your thoughts slip. Do not write them down. The goal is to be unproductive. Try not to doze off during the challenge. Try not to engage in any other activities besides sitting or pacing. Pause the timer if you need to drink water or adjust your posture. I have been trying this for a couple of days. Turns out getting bored for an hour is way harder than, say, focusing on a textbook and study for an hour. I want to post this to see if anyone is interested in such a format. Write me emails about what more I can do to get the most out of this challenge. Feel free to join me on this journey as well. Let me know if you do!

entry.title: When Every Day Feels the Same
entry.summary:
I woke up this morning with a sense of déjà vu. My alarm hadn't gone off yet, but I was already awake, rolling over in bed with a familiar sense of dread. The routine was the same: get ready for work, make coffee, and head to my home office to start the work day. As I attended meetings, smiled for the camera, and updated my product roadmap for what felt like the millionth time, that same feeling stayed— I’ve done this before. This feeling has been with me since yesterday, last week, months before, and maybe even longer. It’s like living in my own version of Groundhog Day1, where every day is identical to the day before. I wake up too early (for me, at least)2, work all day, and by the end of my work day, I'm so drained (emotionally and mentally) that all I want to do is curl up in a ball and sleep. The only break to this repetition is the weekends, and even then, I try not to think about work. I can’t help but ask myself, is this really all there is to life? Ugh, I think I just need a vacation. 16/100 💬 Community Echoes the coffee quest by oak Everyday feels like Sunday by Bearly Significant Reply by email A movie from 1993 where “A narcissistic, self-centered weatherman finds himself in a time loop on Groundhog Day.” I’m not narcissistic but I do feel like I’m stuck in some loop I want to break free from.↩
I’m not a morning person↩

entry.title: Anti-Resume
entry.summary: I saw this really cool post on Twitter and thought I'd make my own version of it Here's my anti-resume, I don't specialise in any particular programming language. To me, languages are just syntax on top of ideologies and principles. I've come to appreciate the essence of programming itself. I don't follow clean code, I don't follow any programming patterns. When I write code I only strive for simplicity. I overvalue simplicity, to the point that I believe that its the most critical thing when it comes to software development. I don't like it when I see python one-liner in a codebase I do a lot of recreational coding. I don't care a lot about how many people use the things I build. I build things simply because I love building things. I love Lua, it's beautiful. Again, I like simplicity in things, when I code in any other language, I usually use a subset of its features. I don't like using iterators over loops, I don't do operator overloading, I don't like it when languages offer multiple ways of accomplishing the same thing. This is also the reason I'm starting to like C. I rely a lot on intuition. I’m not a fan of TDD. I value data structures over algorithms. I don't like Jira. I often end up not using it during projects. I don't like Docker either, I try to avoid it whenever possible. I prefer monoliths over microservices. While microservices can be useful, I think they are often misused. I'm not very good at math. I need a pen and a paper whenever I encounter problems involving matrices, trigonometry, or anything beyond basic math That's it for now :)
